However, in post-production, Google now subjects all photos to an automated process of blurring people's faces and licence plates. In addition, anyone can request specific images be removed from the site. "The privacy concerns could be pretty severe for some and people can still be identified, even with faces blurred out," Bowman said. Prediction: Sentence 1: Crude oil dips below $43 on news that Russia's justice ministry will not force Yukos to halt sales
